content: I've invited @Alexis Toumi here to explain something about open games with latex enabled, thought I might as well do it in public too in case anyone else is interested. This is the "maximum" generalisation I can think of, which exposes the levers you can pull in the definition to adjust it

The first thing you can do is replace lenses with something that behaves enough like them. Certainly any category of optics works. The maximum generality that works is the thing I called a "category with contexts" in https://arxiv.org/abs/1904.11287. That's a symmetric monoidal category C\mathcal CC together with a "context" monoidal functor C:C×Cop→Set\mathbb C : \mathcal C \times \mathcal C^{op} \to \mathbf{Set}C:C×Cop→Set, plus a little bit more

Where the motivating example is C=Lens\mathcal C = \mathbf{Lens}C=Lens with C((X+,X−),(Y+,Y−))=X+×(Y+→Y−)\mathbb C ((X^+, X^-), (Y^+, Y^-)) = X^+ \times (Y^+ \to Y^-)C((X+,X−),(Y+,Y−))=X+×(Y+→Y−) on objects
That's the first of 2 levels you can pull

The second lever is to replace sets of strategy profiles with objects of a monoidal category M\mathcal MM. That needs to be equipped with a "strategy profiles" functor Σ:M→Set\Sigma : \mathcal M \to \mathbf{Set}Σ:M→Set with a colaxator Δ:Σ(x⊗y)→Σ(x)×Σ(y)\Delta : \Sigma (x \otimes y) \to \Sigma (x) \times \Sigma (y)Δ:Σ(x⊗y)→Σ(x)×Σ(y). It also needs a "valuation" functor P:M→Set\mathcal P : \mathcal M \to \mathbf{Set}P:M→Set (or possibly Mop→Set\mathcal M^{op} \to \mathbf{Set}Mop→Set, I'm not sure - so far I've only needed to use it on objects!) which needs to have a laxator ∇:P(x)×P(y)→P(x⊗y)\nabla : \mathcal P (x) \times \mathcal P (y) \to \mathcal P (x \otimes y)∇:P(x)×P(y)→P(x⊗y)

Where the motivating example is M=Set\mathcal M = \mathbf{Set}M=Set with cartesian product, Σ\SigmaΣ the identity functor and P\mathcal PP powerset (I think contravariant powerset), and ∇\nabla∇ is cartesian product of subsets

And there's a variant which I use equally often - where you just have equilibria instead of general best responses - where it's the same except P\mathcal PP takes every set to B\mathbb BB, and ∇\nabla∇ is logical conjunction

That's the setup. You take an object of OG\mathbf{OG}OG to be an object of C\mathcal CC, and an open game x→yx \to yx→y consists of (1) an object aaa of M\mathcal MM, (2) a function Σ(a)→C(x,y)\Sigma (a) \to \mathcal C (x, y)Σ(a)→C(x,y), and (3) a function Σ(a)×C(x,y)→P(a)\Sigma (a) \times \mathbb C (x, y) \to \mathcal P (a)Σ(a)×C(x,y)→P(a). The rest of the structure is used to define the monoidal category structure on it

Jules Hedges said:

The second lever is to replace sets of strategy profiles with objects of a monoidal category M\mathcal MM. That needs to be equipped with a "strategy profiles" functor Σ:M→Set\Sigma : \mathcal M \to \mathbf{Set}Σ:M→Set.

Isn't it a little redundant to replace Set\mathbf{Set}Set with something that's constrained to be structured over Set\mathbf{Set}Set? By which I mean, why not throw away sets altogether? What do you use the strategy profiles functor for?
Because then the valuations P\mathcal PP can use information that's not present in the set of strategy profiles

Well actually, my original motivation was to fiddle with what equals means for open games, because the default one is weird and broken. My original tweak for M\mathcal MM was a category whose objects are sets of players composing by disjoint union
There's one more obvious step of generalisation, which is to get rid of Set\mathbf{Set}Set and do enriched stuff. But I don't know much about that so I'll leave it for someone else

Jules Hedges said:

Because then the valuations P\mathcal PP can use information that's not present in the set of strategy profiles

Ah gotcha, you're saying "if our spaces of strategies are structured, we can lift the usual arguments up the forgetful functor Σ\SigmaΣ into sets"

I'll record some random thoughts here... Let's use the version of open games where strategies are sets and an open game x→yx \to yx→y is specified by a triple (Σ,p:Σ→C(x,y),b:C(x,y)→Rel(Σ))(\Sigma, p : \Sigma \to C(x,y), b : \mathbb{C}(x,y) \to Rel(\Sigma))(Σ,p:Σ→C(x,y),b:C(x,y)→Rel(Σ)).

I think it might be fruitful to consider the category of games with a fixed strategy set Σ\SigmaΣ, let's call it GΣG_\SigmaGΣ​. The composite of two games (p,b)(p, b)(p,b) and (p′,b′)(p', b')(p′,b′) is then given by the play function σ↦p(σ)p′(σ)\sigma \mapsto p(\sigma) p'(\sigma)σ↦p(σ)p′(σ) and best response relation given by [h,k](σ)↦b[h,kp′(σ)](σ)×b′[p(σ)h,k](σ)h,k \mapsto bh,kp'(\sigma) \times b'p(\sigma)h,k[h,k](σ)↦b[h,kp′(σ)](σ)×b′[p(σ)h,k](σ)

If we have a function f:Σ→Σ′f : \Sigma \to \Sigma'f:Σ→Σ′, then we get a pullback functor GΣ′→GΣG_{\Sigma'} \to G_\SigmaGΣ′​→GΣ​: on (p,b)(p, b)(p,b) we just precompose ppp with fff, and post-compose bbb with Rel(f)Rel(f)Rel(f), because RelRelRel acts contravariantly. If we're lucky this all fits together into a pseudofunctor Setop→Cat\mathrm{Set}^\mathrm{op} \to \mathrm{Cat}Setop→Cat, and then the Grothendieck construction should give a category of open games 'GGG'.

This isn't exactly what we want though, composition in 'GGG' is not the kind of composition that takes the product of the strategy sets. But we can implement that composition ourselves using the pullback functors. If we want to compose two games with strategy sets Σ\SigmaΣ and Σ′\Sigma'Σ′ then we pull each of them back to Σ×Σ′\Sigma \times \Sigma'Σ×Σ′ along the projections, and then calculate the composite in GΣ×Σ′G_{\Sigma \times \Sigma'}GΣ×Σ′​. I think this unwinds to the right kind thing in the end?

We might also be interested in cells between open games. Here we can use the fact that Rel(Σ)Rel(\Sigma)Rel(Σ) is a poset under inclusion. So we might define (p,b)≤(p′,b′)(p, b) \leq (p', b')(p,b)≤(p′,b′) when p=p′p = p'p=p′ and b[h,k]≤b′[h,k]b[h,k] \leq b'[h,k]b[h,k]≤b′[h,k]. Each GΣG_\SigmaGΣ​ is (hopefully) then poset-enriched, and maybe that transfers to 'GGG' somehow?

I'm not sure if this is going anywhere but it could be a neat way to package up everything.

Yep. I worked out most of this, whatever I did work write down should be in https://arxiv.org/abs/1711.07059. I remember working out that [open games, morphisms of open games] is fibred over Set, and the pullback operation you wrote down is actually really useful in practice

I think I missed this part though. That's compatibility between the fibred structure of the vertical category with horizontal composition. I wonder if this thing has a name.... a fibred bicategory? [technically I have a double category of open games, but morally same thing for this purposes]

The last thing you wrote is the obvious monoidal bicategory structure of open games. It turns out that in order to make it do anything useful you need to extend it to a monoidal double category. But it also turns out that there's (at least) 2 different inequivalent ways of doing that, which do different useful things. So it's fun, can't just write down the One True Answer and be done

The fact that each fibre over a fixed Σ\SigmaΣ is posetal is quite convenient, because it means infinitely repeated decision processes are just greatest fixpoints in a poset, which are easier to handle than final coalgebras in a double category
(You get an idea of how much knowledge about open games just exists in my head because I always get distracted from writing it down......)

I don't think the 'GGG' I described is quite the same thing as Gamev\mathrm{Game}_vGamev​ from your paper.

In 'GGG' the objects are pairs of a set Σ\SigmaΣ and an object x∈Cx \in Cx∈C. A morphism (Σ,x)→(Σ′,y)(\Sigma, x) \to (\Sigma', y)(Σ,x)→(Σ′,y) is given by a function f:Σ→Σ′f : \Sigma \to \Sigma'f:Σ→Σ′ and a game x→yx \to yx→y with strategy set Σ\SigmaΣ. (Yes this is a bit silly, the fff and the Σ′\Sigma'Σ′ are not particularly involved)

In Gamev\mathrm{Game}_vGamev​, if I'm reading correctly, the objects are triples of x,y∈Cx, y \in Cx,y∈C and a game x→yx \to yx→y. And a morphism (x,y,g)→(x′,y′,g′)(x,y,g) \to (x',y',g')(x,y,g)→(x′,y′,g′) has a bunch of components.
I should have been more explicit when defining GΣG_\SigmaGΣ​, I mean the category with objects the same objects as CCC, and morphisms x→yx \to yx→y given by games with strategy set Σ\SigmaΣ.
